additional_lessons.title: Basic Positions - Offense
additional_lessons.description: Learn the key offensive positions and their roles

variant.prompt_richtext: Who throws most of the passes on offense?
variant.explanation_richtext: The quarterback (QB) is the leader of the offense and throws most passes. They also hand the ball off to running backs and sometimes run themselves.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which position primarily carries the ball on running plays?
variant.explanation_richtext: Running backs (RB) are the main ball carriers on run plays. They take handoffs from the QB and try to gain yards. They can also catch passes.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which players line up wide and catch passes?
variant.explanation_richtext: Wide receivers (WR) line up near the sidelines and run routes to catch passes from the QB. They're usually the fastest players on offense.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main job of the offensive line?
options_json: Protect the QB and create running lanes
variant.explanation_richtext: The offensive line (5 big players) protects the QB from being tackled and blocks defenders to create running lanes for the running back.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which offensive lineman snaps the ball to the quarterback?
variant.explanation_richtext: The center is the middle offensive lineman who snaps (hikes) the ball to the QB to start each play. They're crucial for starting plays smoothly.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which position can both block like a lineman and catch passes like a receiver?
variant.explanation_richtext: The tight end (TE) is a hybrid position - they line up next to the offensive line and can either block defenders or run routes to catch passes.

variant.prompt_richtext: How many offensive players are on the field at once?
variant.explanation_richtext: There are always 11 players on offense (and 11 on defense). Having too many or too few players on the field results in a penalty.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is it called when the center gives the ball to the QB to start a play?
variant.explanation_richtext: The snap is when the center hikes the ball between his legs to the QB. This starts every offensive play. The QB usually yells signals before the snap.

additional_lessons.title: Basic Positions - Defense
additional_lessons.description: Learn the key defensive positions and their roles

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main goal of the defense?
variant.explanation_richtext: The defense tries to stop the offense from scoring and gaining yards. They can also score by getting interceptions or fumbles and running them back.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which defensive players line up right across from the offensive line?
variant.explanation_richtext: Defensive linemen (DL) line up on the line of scrimmage across from offensive linemen. They try to tackle the QB or running back and stop runs.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which defenders play behind the defensive line and can both rush the QB and cover receivers?
variant.explanation_richtext: Linebackers (LB) are versatile defenders who play behind the D-line. They stop runs, rush the QB, and cover receivers - they do it all!

variant.prompt_richtext: Which defenders primarily cover wide receivers?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cornerbacks (CB) are fast defenders who line up across from wide receivers. Their main job is to prevent receivers from catching passes.

variant.prompt_richtext: Which defenders play deepest in the secondary and are the 'last line of defense'?
variant.explanation_richtext: Safeties (S) play deep in the secondary (defensive backfield). They prevent long passes and are the last defenders who can stop a touchdown.

variant.prompt_richtext: What must the defense do to stop an offensive play?
variant.explanation_richtext: To stop a play, the defense must tackle (bring down) the player carrying the ball. The play ends when the ball carrier is tackled or goes out of bounds.

variant.prompt_richtext: How many defensive players are on the field at once?
variant.explanation_richtext: There are always 11 defensive players on the field, matching the 11 offensive players. Both teams must have exactly 11 players.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'secondary' in football?
variant.explanation_richtext: The secondary refers to the defensive backs - cornerbacks and safeties. They're called the secondary because they're the second level of defense behind the line and linebackers.

additional_lessons.title: The Field & Yard Lines
additional_lessons.description: Understand the football field layout and how to read yard lines

variant.prompt_richtext: How long is a football field from end zone to end zone?
variant.explanation_richtext: The playing field is 100 yards long (not counting the end zones). Each end zone adds 10 yards, making the total field 120 yards.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is special about the 50-yard line?
options_json: It's the middle of the field
variant.explanation_richtext: The 50-yard line is exactly in the middle of the field, 50 yards from each end zone. It's also called midfield.

variant.prompt_richtext: The ball is at the 25-yard line. How far is it from the nearest end zone?
variant.explanation_richtext: Yard lines show the distance to the nearest end zone. At the 25-yard line, the ball is 25 yards away from scoring a touchdown.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the line that separates the field from the end zone called?
variant.explanation_richtext: The goal line is the line at the front of each end zone. When the ball crosses this line, it's a touchdown!

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the imaginary line where the ball is placed before each play called?
variant.explanation_richtext: The line of scrimmage is where the ball is spotted. Both teams line up on either side of it, and the play starts when the ball is snapped.

variant.prompt_richtext: What are the short lines running down the field between the yard lines?
variant.explanation_richtext: Hash marks are the small lines that run down the field. The ball is always placed on or between the hash marks, never too close to the sidelines.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the area inside the opponent's 20-yard line called?
variant.explanation_richtext: The red zone is the area from the 20-yard line to the goal line. It's called this because the offense is close to scoring and the defense must be on high alert!

variant.prompt_richtext: What happens when a player with the ball steps on or crosses the sideline?
options_json: The play is over and the clock stops
variant.explanation_richtext: When a player goes out of bounds (crosses the sideline), the play ends immediately and the clock stops. The ball is placed where they went out.
